definition: to grab/to snatch up/variant of 焯[chao1]
a flashy lifestyle/to live it up

sentences.english: The more indulgent the gift the greater the suspicion it seems.
sentences.chinese: 越是阔绰大手笔的礼物越是使人产生更大的怀疑。
达尔文在贝格尔号上“阔绰”的住处。

sentences.english: And luxury lies not in richness and ornateness but in the absence of vulgarity .
sentences.chinese: 奢华并不依存于阔绰和华丽，而是显现在不粗俗之中。

sentences.english: With even the biggest spenders starting to scrimp, luxury companies from Chanel S.
sentences.chinese: 眼下，即便是以前出手最阔绰的人也开始精打细算了。

sentences.english: How did these guys all get so rich?
sentences.chinese: 这些家伙是怎么变得如此阔绰的？

sentences.english: Mrs. Sha must have had a sugar daddy on the side.
sentences.chinese: 沙太太肯定有个阔绰的老情夫在暗中资助她。

sentences.english: He attempts to woo her in a characteristically extravagant manner.
sentences.chinese: 他尝试过用挥金如土的阔绰方式去取悦于她。

sentences.english: Martin had even been extravagant m the strength of those on ten storiettes.
sentences.chinese: 可马丁却早已仗恃那十篇小故事过起了阔绰的生活。

sentences.english: Chinese golfers tend to be even higher spenders than Americans, Cantlay says.
sentences.chinese: 一些中国的高尔夫球手甚至比美国球手还出手阔绰。

definition: lit. stake a thousand pieces of gold on one throw (idiom); to throw away money recklessly/extravagant
lit. to squander money like dirt (idiom)/fig. to spend money like water/extravagant
expert/scholar/mother earth/a type of green tea
rich and powerful/rich and influential person/big shot
extravagant (idiom); to throw away money by the handful/wasteful
